Large, singular cake: Chocolate cakes are generally larger in size and meant to serve multiple portions, whereas cupcakes are individual servings.
Slicing: Chocolate cakes are typically sliced into pieces for serving, while cupcakes are already portioned and do not require slicing.
Shape: Chocolate cakes are usually round, square, or rectangular in shape, while cupcakes are nearly always round with a domed top.
Icing coverage: A chocolate cake often has icing spread over a larger surface area, including the sides, while cupcakes usually have icing only on the top.
Cake stand or platter: Chocolate cakes are often presented on a cake stand or a large platter, whereas cupcakes are usually displayed on a tray, stand, or in a baking tin.

Shell shape: Escargots have spiraled, conical shells, while mussels have smooth, elongated, oval or teardrop-shaped shells.
Texture: Escargots' shells are typically rougher compared to the smoother, shinier shells of mussels.

Serving style: Escargots are often served in specialized dishes with individual compartments or on small plates, sometimes with garlic butter or other sauces. Mussels are usually served in larger bowls, often with broth or a similar liquid.
Size: Escargots' shells are generally smaller compared to the typically larger size of mussel shells.
Color: Escargots' shells can be various shades of brown, while mussel shells tend to be dark blue, black, or brown with a shiny finish.
Shape of animal: The edible part of escargots has extended bodies with a clear head and tentacles, whereas mussels have a more uniform, lumpier appearance.

Texture: French toast has a spongy, bread-like texture, often with a golden-brown crust, while French fries have a smooth or slightly crispy exterior.

Presentation: French toast is typically served in a stack or as individual slices, whereas French fries are usually piled together.

Rice grains: Fried rice consists of separate grains of rice, whereas Pad Thai is made with stir-fried rice noodles.
Vegetables: Fried rice typically includes mixed vegetables such as peas, carrots, and corn, while Pad Thai often has bean sprouts and sometimes scallions.
Protein: Fried rice might include a mix of egg, shrimp, chicken, or pork, whereas Pad Thai commonly includes shrimp, chicken, or tofu.
Garnishes: Fried rice is usually garnished with green onions and sometimes sesame seeds, whereas Pad Thai is often topped with crushed peanuts, lime wedges, and sometimes cilantro.
Color: Fried rice can range in color from light to dark depending on soy sauce and other seasonings used, while Pad Thai often has a light brown or reddish hue from tamarind paste and fish sauce.
Texture: Fried rice has a drier, slightly oily texture, while Pad Thai has a slightly sticky, moist texture due to the sauce.
Egg: While both dishes may contain egg, in fried rice the egg is often scrambled throughout, whereas in Pad Thai the egg is usually mixed in and cooked with the noodles.

Whole seafood: Mussels are typically served in their shells, whereas lobster bisque often has pieces of lobster within the soup or is a pureed blend.

Texture: The texture of mussels in their shells is solid and chewy, while lobster bisque is a thick, smooth liquid.
Serving dish: Mussels are often served in a bowl or plate with the shells visible, whereas lobster bisque is usually served in a bowl without shells.

Shells: Mussels have hard, often dark-colored shells, while dumplings have soft, doughy exteriors.

Shape: Pork chops are generally larger and have a more uniform, rectangular or oval shape, whereas chicken wings are smaller and have a distinct, irregular shape with two main parts (drumette and flat).
Color: Pork chops are typically a consistent pinkish-red color when raw, while chicken wings can vary from white to light pink.
Bone structure: Pork chops usually have a single rib bone or no bone, while chicken wings have a more complex bone structure with multiple small bones.
Marbling: Pork chops often have visible fat marbling throughout the meat, whereas chicken wings have less intramuscular fat but may have more external skin and fat.
Thickness: Pork chops are usually thicker cuts of meat, while chicken wings are generally thinner, with less meat on them.
Texture: The muscle fibers in pork chops tend to be firmer and more tightly packed compared to the softer, less dense muscle fibers in chicken wings.
Lighter color: Pork chops tend to be lighter pink or beige, while steaks are usually a deeper red.
Bone shape: Pork chops often have a more uniform, round or "T" shaped bone, whereas steak bones can be irregular and varied in shape.
Marbling: Pork chops usually have less internal fat marbling compared to steaks.
Size and thickness: Pork chops are generally smaller in size and more uniform in thickness compared to steaks.
Fat cap: Pork chops often have a distinct white fat cap along one edge, whereas steaks can have fat distributed differently.
Texture: Pork tends to have a slightly finer grain texture compared to the coarser texture of beef.

Shape: Steaks are typically irregularly shaped cuts, whereas hot dogs are uniformly cylindrical.
Texture: Steaks have a fibrous, marbled texture, while hot dogs have a smooth, homogenous appearance.
Size: Steaks are generally larger and thicker compared to the thin, elongated shape of hot dogs.
Grill marks: Steaks often have grill or sear marks, whereas hot dogs may show grill marks but often have a more uniform appearance.
Juices: Steaks tend to release natural juices and may have visible fat, whereas hot dogs are more processed and less likely to show natural juicing.
Color: Steaks often display a range of colors from pink or red (when raw) to brown (when cooked), while hot dogs are usually a uniform, processed meat color.
Bone: Some steaks may have a bone attached, whereas hot dogs do not.

Rice: Sushi typically includes vinegared rice, often formed into bite-sized pieces.
Seaweed: Many types of sushi are wrapped in seaweed (nori), either on the outside or inside.
Raw fish: Sushi often features slices of raw fish or seafood on top of or inside the rice.
Roll shape: Sushi can come in rolls (maki) with various ingredients inside the rice and seaweed.
Plate arrangement: Sushi is usually presented in individual pieces or small rolls, often neatly arranged.
Garnishes: Sushi is commonly accompanied by soy sauce, wasabi, and pickled ginger.
Chopsticks: Sushi is often eaten with chopsticks (though this alone is not a definitive feature).
Broth: A clear, aromatic soup broth as the base.
Noodles: Rice noodles submerged in the broth.
Meat and herbs: Typically includes sliced meat (such as beef or chicken) and garnished with fresh herbs like basil, cilantro, and bean sprouts.
Bowls: Pho is typically served in bowls.
